course_title: Topics: Environmental Studies: Nature's Benefits to People
class_notes: There is growing recognition that nature generates substantial benefits to people (aka ecosystem services) in many ways and that it is in society's self-interest to incorporate understanding of those benefits into decision making. In this course, students will explore 1) what those benefits are, i.e. climate mitigation, urban cooling, coastal protection, as well as physical and mental health, 2) the approaches and challenges to quantifying the value those benefits provide, either through economic markets or intrinsic value; 3) how those benefits and values are mapped spatially; 4) approaches to revealing patterns of distributional inequity for nature's benefits; and 5) how policy-makers are attempting to integrate knowledge of nature's benefits into decisions at local, regional and global scales.
course_description: Variable topics that are offered as irregular courses. Past course topics have included: Finding Place: Technology, Stories, and the Environment; Introduction to Botany; Environment, Health, and Development; Conservation and Development; Booms and Busts in Resources of Georgia; and Paleoecology.
